message_1:
Suppose a car manufacturing company wants to test the fuel efficiency of their new car model. They randomly select 25 cars of the same model and drive them under identical conditions. The mean fuel efficiency of these 25 cars is found to be 34 miles per gallon with a standard deviation of 2.5 miles per gallon. 

The company wants to know with 95% confidence, what is the true mean fuel efficiency of the car model (assuming the sample is representative of the population). 

What is the lower and upper bound of the confidence interval for the true mean fuel efficiency of the car model?
message_2:
To calculate the 95% confidence interval for the true mean fuel efficiency of the car model, we will use the following formula:

Confidence interval = sample mean ± (critical value * standard error)

The critical value for a 95% confidence interval with a normal distribution is 1.96. The standard error is calculated as the standard deviation divided by the square root of the sample size:

Standard error = standard deviation / √sample size = 2.5 / √25 = 2.5 / 5 = 0.5

Now, we can calculate the confidence interval:

Lower bound = 34 - (1.96 * 0.5) = 34 - 0.98 = 33.02 miles per gallon
Upper bound = 34 + (1.96 * 0.5) = 34 + 0.98 = 34.98 miles per gallon

So, with 95% confidence, the true mean fuel efficiency of the car model is between 33.02 and 34.98 miles per gallon.
